title: Japan fans want Jamie Ritchie punished after shocking elbow during win over Scotland
text:
Scotland star Jamie Ritchie appeared to elbow Will Tupou during Japan’s win (Picture: ITV)

Japan supporters are calling for Jamie Ritchie to face retrospective punishment after the flanker appeared to elbow Will Tupou during the hosts’ thrilling 28-21 victory over Scotland.

The result meant Scotland crashed out at the World Cup pool stage for only the second time in their history, while the Brave Blossoms sailed into the quarter-finals with a 100 per cent record in the tournament.

Jamie Joseph’s side produced a masterclass in attacking rugby after going behind to Finn Russel’s early try in Yokohama, with Kotaro Matsushima, Keita Inagaki and Kenki Fukuoka all touching down in a breathless first half.

Fukuoka soon added his second to further extend Japan’s lead before WP Nel and Zander Fagerson crossed over for Scotland to set up a nail-biting finish.

Japan fans are calling for Ritchie to face retrospective punishment (Picture: Getty)

But Gregor Townsend’s men, needing to win by more than four points, could not prevent defeat meaning Japan cruised through as Pool A winners along with second-placed Ireland.

Ireland must now prepare for a titanic quarter-final clash against New Zealand, while Japan must beat South Africa to secure a place in the last four.

Ritchie was arguably Scotland’s standout performer on Sunday, but the openside flanker was widely condemned for a moment in the 48th minute at the Nissan Stadium.

The Edinburgh star pushed Tupou’s face into the ground with his elbow after the Japan full-back’s judo-style tackle on Tommy Seymour.

Referee Ben O’Keeffe allowed the game to continue and Japan fans were left stunned as Ritchie came away unpunished.

Scotland head coach Townsend insisted his side will bounce back from their miserable World Cup campaign in the aftermath of their defeat to Japan.

‘There’s a lot more in this team,’ he said.

‘Experiences are what make you as a group and how you react to those experiences.

‘It was a unique situation we were in tonight. We always knew it was going to be a challenge playing against Japan given our short turnaround from the Russia game.

Townsend hopes his players learn from their mistakes (Picture: Getty)

‘We had the team and we had the ability at the start of that game to go on and win it by the necessary amount of points.

‘That we didn’t is hugely disappointing. We have to learn from that.

‘We don’t get another turn at the World Cup for four years but we’ve got to improve as we get to next tournament which is the Six Nations in three months’ time.’
